39439689.review:
Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus non è il secondo capitolo della pentalogia di Oddworld: il progetto originale doveva vedere cinque protagonisti differenti ognuno nella sua relativa avventura, ma poi Oddworld Inhabitants è sparita dalla scena senza preavviso dopo essere riuscita a produrre solo due dei cinque capitoli previsti (Abe's Oddysee e Munch's Oddysee). Abe's Exoddus è più considerato come un capitolo bonus di Oddysee (a cui per inciso verrà dedicato un remake apparentemente col nome di Oddworld Soulstorm), sostanzialmente quello che è a tutti gli effetti un more of the same più espanso e completo. 
Sono infatti presenti le stesse identiche meccaniche del primo basate sul platforming 2D a schermate fisse e movimenti rigidi, il gameplay è rimasto pressochè identico, ma qui abbiamo nuove e più variegate ambientazioni (gli Slig Barracks, il Bonewerkz e il Necron su tutte), un sistema vocale più ricco e completo - finalmente è possibile impartire ordini a più mudokon contemporaneamente -, è possibile la possessione di specie aggiuntive tra cui Scrab, Paramiti e Glukkon con relativi comandi vocali, è triplicato il numero di Mudokon da salvare, grafica migliorata per fondali molto più ricchi e definiti, atmosfera ancora da vendere, gli status dei Mudokon (arrabbiato, cieco, euforico, depresso) che introducono nuove meccaniche e relative sfide, nuovi nemici tra cui gli Slig volanti, i Greeters e i Fleeches, insomma un sacco di roba nuova che rende Abe's Exoddus un gioco più completo e longevo.
Non mancherò di prendere Oddworld Soulstorm se anch'esso come New 'n' Tasty si rivelerà essere un remake di prim'ordine, ma nel frattempo coloro che ancora, incredibilmente, non hanno giocato Abe's Exoddus possono tranquillamente spendere questi due cornetti e reimmergersi in un mondo davvero molto Odd.

Después de los sucesos ocurridos en "Abe's Odyssey", nuestro querido protagonista se entera de que hay otros lugares similares a las [i]Granjas Hostiles[/i] y con la supuesta ayuda de unos imbeciles mudokons deciden partir en busqueda de dichos sitios, luego de una larga caminata logran llegar a su destino y se entera que están usando a su gente para productos comerciales, una vez más, Abe, se pone manos a la obra.

37721030.review:
Jako malý jsem se dohrál někam těsně za půlku, protože v tý době jsem měl co dělat se závislostí na Falloutech. Po mnoha letech, jsem se do Oddworldu, díky Steamu, ponořil znova a i přes svůj věk mi hra poskytla vynikajícní zážitek. 
Puzzle založené na jednoduchých principech herního světa. Plusem je, že jsou velmi pochopitelné, takže každému hned dojde, kdy má použít stín, kdy chodit po špičkách, že mina se zneškodňuje při zeleném světýlku, že hafany můžu odlákat kostí, že smějící se plechovky reagují na pohyb, že se nemůžu převtělovat do nepřátel, když je kolem červené oko, která jde ale často nějak rozbít... Originální je především zmiňované vtělování se do jiných postav/zvířat, kdy se opět mění gameplay (za Sliga většinou střílečka, za bezrukého Glukkona komandování Sligů a otevírání dveří na hlasové kódy, zvířata se jediná po "odvtělení" nerozprsknou, takže ty se většinou odvádějí někam stranou, aby sme před nimi mohli zdrhat...). Prostě se střídají pasáže plížecí, zdrhací a pasáže, kdy se musí zjistit, kudy kam a s kym. Kamarád hru označil za kravinu, protože se můžu vtělit do svého explozivního prdu a navádět ho. Mě to přišlo naprosto logické. Explozivní prd mám po vypití šťávy, dělané z kostí Muddokonů, v nichž sídlí jejich duše, které následně ovládnu. :) 
Ačkoliv z prostředí je pouze továrna - jungle - jeskyně - továrna, stejně se vzhledově tváří pokaždé jinak. Co se mi ale líbilo, je takové morbidně komediální zpracování hry. Ačkoliv jedna rasa zotročila druhou, používá jí na maso/kosti/slzy a bůhvícoještě, stejně se dokážu zasmát, když Abe dělá v animacích šaškárny. Stejně jako (alespoň ze začátku), sem se smál u několika smrtí, z nichž vede sežrání malinkatou housenkou. Další příklad morbidní komedie jsou právě smrtě. Hrajete za roztomilou postavičku, kterou pořád trhají na kusy miny, nechá se rozmixovat vrtákama, rozstřílet, pády z výšky, vaporizovat... chvíli vám jí je líto, chvíli se tomu smějete. 
Prostě i po letech, je to jedna z nejlepších plošinovek, co sem měl tu čest si zahrát.

Pro: Humor, puzzle, postavy, svět, herní principy, Abe, lítající Slig

Proti: Některé zdrhací pasáže, u kterých se počítá každá vteřina

36937751.review:
Abe's Exoddus mantiene la filosofía de su antecesor. Sin cambiar la fórmula, potencia todas las bondades de Abe's Oddysee y retoca algunas cuestiones referidas a la jugabilidad. El diseño y estilo propio del juego se mantienen intactas. En esta ocasión contaremos con mucho más variados escenarios, trabajados, dignos de ser contemplados, considerando el tiempo de esta entrega. Compra obligada junto con el primero, sus precios son módicos. Si te enganchás, puedes adquirir el remake del primero, también por bajo costo (en época de rebajas), y esperar por la nueva entrega.

La duración del juego puede variar mucho dependiendo de la habilidad y del jugador. Completarlo al 100% te llevará entre 8-10 horas contemplando todas las pruebas de "ensayo y error" que pasaremos en el transcurso del mismo.

Sin dudas, es un clásico de las plataformas, original en cuanto a su diseño, no tanto en su mecánica (heredado del antiquísimo ya, Prince of Persia). Una banda sonora aceptable que nos acompaña en los momentos álgidos de la aventura.

Recomendado desde todo punto de vista.

Continuation of the adventures of "terrorist" Abe, new elements of gameplay, new puzzles and new enemies, including the Glukkons. Personally, the game seemed boring in some places, but it's likely that I immediately started playing after passing the previous game.

The game has a some of problems:
- If you play for a long time, some sort of slow motions begins (the restart heals it)

35469246.review:
This game is a perfect example of why plataformers were so popular in the 90s. It will test your skill and reflexes, and will also deliver scenarios where you'll need to be clever to continue, which makes progress very rewarding. You control a humanoid creature called Abe who has no fighting skills at all, you only means to attack will be whatever the environment provides you (most notably mind control, but also grenades or even explosive farts :D).

The objective of the game is to save your fellow mudokons (creatures similar to you), who you guide by talking to them and telling them what to do; while staying out of the many dangers presented to you and them. It is a difficult game by today's standards, but the learning curve is balanced enough to let you learn the mechanics before becoming really challenging (secret areas are challenging from the very begging tho, so beware). Also the presence of a quicksave feature will make the journey less tedious.

The game is not very long (long enough for its price tag tho), but its packed with secret areas that are more challenging than the main game and will extend the playthrough time. Sadly there's little replay value (except maybe for saving them all / killing them all), but i enjoy playing it over again from time to time.

Runs perfect in my low end pc, I haven't had any issue so far.

A timeless classic, a sequel that improves its predecessor, and a must-have if you even remotely like plataforming or stealth games.

35438473.review:
One of my favourite games of all time. I replay this game and its prequel every year or so.

Abe has tight and weighty movement controls. Some might take a while to get use to it, but it is very intentional and they are better implimented than many other cinematic platformers.
The game is full of fanastically designed enviomental puzzles. Requiring stealth, timing, problem solving, possession of enemies and of course gamespeak, which is a mechanic that allows Abe to communicate with his fellow slaves to attempt to rescue them. "Hello" "Hello" "Follow Me" "Okay".

Fanastic visual art design all around. Character design and animation, background art, and the atmosphere and mood of oddworld are all absurdly well crafted, especially for the time of release.
The sound design and music is top notch. Nice psuedo-industrial, ambient pieces that add so much to the atmosphere.

Also your money goes straight to Oddworld Inhabitants to help develop more Oddworld games in the future (minus what goes to Valve of course), no publisher taking major cuts.

Highly recommended, along with Abes Oddysee.

31887479.review:
[b]You might like if[/b]: You loved the Playstation version and want to sock it to the Magog Cartel once more... but don't mind a shaky port to do it with.

Incredible game... not so good port.

Think you're badass because you lit your own fart? Kid... I made mine explode and knock out a security orb. Your move, bucko.

Great news! They have got rid of the meat saws!

... now it's bone saws.

Abe's Exoddus is the sequel to the Abe's Oddysee; keeping everything that made that game fantastic, fixing anything that wasn't... and adding a truckload more content. It retains the difficulty but feels a lot more approachable, particularly where the Quicksave gives you an on-the-fly checkpoint you can go back to before pulling off anything particularly fiddly (believe me, you'll need it). There's more to possess, new problems to be solved (slap-wars between your comrades being one of the funnier ones) and a whopping 300 Mudokons to save. So suffice to say: An utterly masterful execution that enshrined its place as a classic on the PlayStation. If you enjoyed the original, then there's little reason you wouldn't adore this one too.

... That is... if you can handle some of the annoying quirks from the port (same problems as Oddysee, I'm afraid):

[list]
    [*]Overall game speed is faster (maybe 20%?). Have you tried disarming a bomb at high speed? Don't do it.

    [*]Controller mapping is shaky - We've lost the L2/R2 buttons where it doesn't recognise the triggers on most controllers. It's also a sod to configure as well, unless you know which is button 1, 2, 3, 4... Not unworkable, but fiddly and takes some getting used to.

    [*]The game stretches to full screen... which [i]really[/i] doesn't flatter it. I'd personally prefer the option to let it retain its native resolution and run with the black sidebars (akin to the screenshots on the store page).
[/list]

If these 3 could get sorted, then I'd recommend this game without hesitation. Easily the most formidable and enjoyable of the entire Oddworld series, and would otherwise be a joyous nostalgia trip into how much I hate Fleeches and damn their very existence into the bowels of a Glukkon's backside. In its current state, however, it's a little hard to enjoy.

31541332.review:
Aunque originalmente se planeó que la saga 'Oddworld' estuviese compuesta por cinco entregas protagonizadas cada una por un héroe distinto, el enorme éxito de 'Oddworld Abe's Oddysee' llevó a sus desarrolladores a sacar lo que ellos mismos denominaron como "juegos bonus". Este tipo de títulos se dedicarían a ampliar la historia de este fantástico universo rellenando el hueco entre cada una de las entregas principales, de modo que esta entrega serviría como "aperitivo" para el futuro 'Oddworld Munch's Oddysee', que ya venía descrito en el propio manual del juego que analizamos. Después el devenir de la saga iría por otros derroteros, pero esta segunda parte de las aventuras de Abe llegó como un regalo caído del cielo para los usuarios de PlayStation y PC.
A nivel gráfico se repite el mismo esquema que con su predecesor, preciosos fondos prerenderizados con sprites magníficamente animados para representar a los personajes. Pero ahora con nuevas animaciones, nuevas criaturas, y escenarios aún más ricos en detalles y efectos. Las escenas CGI vuelven a ser simplemente magistrales, logrando sumergirnos más todavía en la aventura y en este universo de seres tan sumamente especiales.
También repite la soberbia calidad de la banda sonora, con sus temas ambientales y oscuros que nos acompañarán en todo momento, siguiendo a la perfección el ritmo de la aventura. Lo mismo ocurre con el excelente doblaje al castellano, tan bien adaptado como lo estaba en su predecesor para poder disfrutar al 100% del juego sin necesidad de saber ni gota de inglés. Algo que también se vuelve a aplicar a los letreros y mensajes que nos encontramos por el juego, reflejando una gran pasión y cuidado por el detalle.
El control es exactamente el mismo que el de su predecesor (tampoco hacía falta cambiarlo), pero ahora disponemos de nuevas acciones, como la posibilidad de abofetear a otros mudokons si se ponen algo tontos, o incluso a ciertos enemigos si es que no nos vuelan en pedazos antes. Un mudokon agredido no se lo tomará nada bien, por mucho que lo hagamos con toda la buena intención del mundo. De modo que también habrá una opción para pedir disculpas.
Además ahora podemos hablar a los demás personajes en conjunto o por separado, algo muy útil cuando hay varios implicados en pantalla y queremos hacer las cosas por orden. También habrá que prestar atención al estado de animo de los mudokons, ya que además de enfadados, también podrán estar chiflados, enfermos, deprimidos, e incluso ciegos. Estos últimos dependerán enteramente de nuestras órdenes para no sucumbir a algún peligro por el camino, de modo que nos tocará ser sus ojos.
El estado de ánimo de los personajes será muy importante durante la partida, especialmente si queremos salvar a la mayor cantidad posible de mudokons para completar la aventura como es debido. Por ejemplo los mudokons deprimidos pueden autolesionarse hasta llegar al suicidio, por lo que más nos vale tratarlos con cariño si no queremos perderlos.
Posesión infernal
Otro novedad importante a nivel jugable, es que ahora podremos poseer una mayor variedad de criaturas, como por ejemplos lo scrabs, los paramitas, o incluso los maléficos glukkons. Cada criatura ofrece sus propias características y controles, y saber manejarlos y aprovechar sus capacidades será vital a lo largo del juego. También encontraremos nuevas versiones de viejos enemigos, como los sligs voladores que podremos poseer para surcar los cielos.
Finalmente el arsenal de Abe ahora hace uso de algo que en la primera entrega simplemente servía para darle un toque de humor al juego. ¡Los pedos! En esta ocasión las flatulencias de nuestro flacucho amigo se podrán emplear, no solo para molestar a otros mudokons y hacer que se aparten, si no también como una mortífera arma que podemos poseer y hacer explotar después cuál bomba de control remoto. Para ello bastará con un sorbito de la nueva bebida SoulStorm, que produce efectos así de curiosos en los intestinos de Abe.
¡Sálvalos a todos!
En esta ocasión el juego se extendía a lo largo de dos discos, lo que viene a ser seña clara de una mayor duración que la de su predecesor, y más cuando ambas entregas se parecen tanto en su mecánica. Completar la aventura no será nada fácil, pero menos aún lo será si nos proponemos salvar a todos los mudokons. En tal caso deberemos agudizar y mucho nuestro ingenio, así como poner a prueba toda nuestra pericia plataformera.
Diversión, carisma, jugabilidad, y todo un universo de criaturas fantásticas os esperan en 'Oddworld Abe's Exoddus'. Una verdadera obra maestra a la altura de su predecesor que os mantendrá horas y horas pegados al mando. Sin embargo también hay que advertir de su elevada dificultad, ya que se trata de un reto en toda regla tanto para nuestra mente como para nuestras habilidades de control. Si esto último no es problema para vosotros, no esperéis ni un solo segundo más para haceros con él.

Nota 10/10

29807313.review:
One of the best platformers ever made, Abe's Exooddus is a direct sequel of Abe's Oddysee and features even more levels than it's predecessor, while also bringing the most requested features of the last game, namely the ability to quicksave, restart levels where you messed up and all-talk.

The game features plenty of mechanics and contains sections of stealth, logic, agility and sometimes observance.

To name one of the mechanics that makes this particular game stand out, you have the ability to posses enemies and use them in your advantage to either destroy their own kind or free your path. Every single type of enemy has different types of abilities and limitations and it's up to you to figure them out. Some levels even prevent you from using your powers so you will have to use your brain to find a way around.

The game also throws a challenge at you. Fellow enslaved people of your race are scattered around levels and it's up to you to talk to and lead them to portals that bring them to their freedom. You can either succeed or get them killed in the process, or even ignore them altogether and continue in your journey. You can command them using the talk system, unless they're mad or depressed, where you'll have to console them first, or smack the crap out of those affected by laughing gas.

I personally think that's a very unique mechanic. Sometimes you'll have to clear a whole level then come back to the very beginning and escort your pals. Blind ones are also present and telling them to stop in their path is mandatory for their survival.
You'll be rewarded for saving many of your kind but punished for refusing to or saving too few.


The atmosphere of this game, like the first, is amazing. The story elements, the setting, the soundtrack and the characters make it up for one of the greatest cinematic experiences I've ever experienced. The graphics and the cutscenes are pre-rendered 3D sequences and they look just great for a game that came two decades ago. 

I should probably also mention that this game, unlike other titles on Steam that originally came during the 90's, fully works on both modern and old systems.


I don't really have negative feedback about this game. It's one of the things that made up my childhood and replaying it was a lot of joy. I guess that there were a few annoying levels that felt a bit repetitive(the ones that feature fleeches for instance), but other than that, everything is godlike. I highly recommend this game to anyone.

The game itself is a highly pre-rendered puzzle platformer which takes place in a strange world with weird creatures. You're basically trying to save as many modokons (green aliens) as possible, in various ways. There's 300 mudokons to rescue, you don't have to rescue all of them in order to complete the game, since many of them are hidden in all sorts of sercrets. You have the ability to possess creatures and take control of them, also each of them have their own set of voice commands which can be used to interact with others, it has a unique approach to a dialogue system which is a pretty messy, but it shouldn't get in your way too much.

[b]9/10 - ps1 nostalgia[/b]

If you get stuck at some escape levels, don't forget that the X key makes you instantly roll while you're running, also F5 is a shortcut for quicksave and F6 for quickload.

28038950.review:
Nominated for the “test of time” award. This was my absolute favourite game when I was a kid and I still love it to this day.
It may be partly because I only owned about 3 games at the time but I must've sunk more hours into this game than any other.
The atmosphere and world are great, a dark story with just the right amount of humour. Abe is the last hope to free his enslaved people, who are forced to work in dangerous conditions by greedy slave traders who care only about profit, but if you get bored of all that you can press a button to make Abe fart, which causes all Mudokons next to him to take step back, and those further away to giggle. 
Gameplaywise Abe’s Exoddus is a puzzle-platformer with the emphasis on the platforming over the puzzling. Most of the puzzles are easy to figure out, but actually completing them is another thing. It manages to fall into that elusive sweet spot of “challenging but fair”. You will die a lot but the game rarely resorts to fake-difficult instant-death traps. I remember playing some of these levels for the first time, I almost smashed my keyboard in frustration and yet every time I screwed up I knew it was my own fault. Each failure leaves you even more determined to finally beat this damn level.
This game seems to be less popular than its predecessor, Abe’s Oddysee, (although that may just be my group of friends) but I definitely prefer this one. Partly because I actually played this sequel before the original but also in large part because of the addition of quicksave. There is nothing more frustrating than completing a particularly difficult section and then dying 3 steps from a checkpoint and the quicksave handily eliminates that frustration.
The graphics are somewhat dated but it still looks pretty good for its age, besides it’s only $3 - or even less if you wait for a sale - what more could you want? Highly recommended, especially for any fans of old-school platformers.

26702851.review:
This Game. Just, this game.

If you're planning on getting this game at the moment, don't let anything put you off. When I was a lot younger, owning this game on the PS3 [Yes, I am still one of those little turds who still attend school], I didn't like it. But now? It's one of the best games I've played in a while.  So if you're new to this series, here's a review for you to settle you in. Well, as best as I can.

[h1]The Plot[/h1]


So the plot is simple: Abe, the Mudokon who was formerly a floor-waxer for Rupture Farms before blowing it up, finds out of a despicable plan by the Glukkons through a group of dead spirits named The Three Weirdos. The burial ground of Necrum had been stolen from; bones were being mined by blinded Mudokons, as they were a required ingredient or the well-known beverage Soulstorm Brew. Upon finding this out, Abe sets out to Destroy the brewery and stop this new industrialist scheme. An okay plot, if I say so myself, despite being along similar lines as Oddysee.


[h1] Controls: Movement, Gamespeak & Posession[/h1]



The gameplay is quite something. So let's get this out the way. Abe's normal controls, walking, running, rolling, jumping and all sorts are really smooth in a sense. They're responsive and flow well with the pace of the game, whether it be slow platforming or heart-pounding chases, and trust me, there are going to be lots of those. You're probably going to spend a lot of the time either walking, rolling or sneaking, as running is mainly essential for chases with Sligs, Scrabs and Paramites, which do crop up at just the right times. Jumping is precise and easy to do, y'just press the space button and you'll leap about two to three spaces forwards, which you learn and can pretty much master right off the bat. In fact, most movement CAN be learnt that quickly. And sneaking is just walking, 'cept Sligs can't hear you. Dead simple, and with a noise I can't get out of my head for some reason.

Gamespeak. This nifty mechanic allows Abe to talk to his enslaved race and lead them to bird portals. A lot are simple: Hello, follow me, all of ya', wait, all that stuff. However, replacing the whistling from the last game, there are now options to slap, say sorry, tell people to stop. This was because in this game, the Mudokons have several emotions to work around, going from sad and angry, the blind Mudokons who will follow the sound of your voice but not you, or sick Mudokons who you have to heal with ring powers. There isn't much else to say here. Nifty.

Posession is something that got a direct upgrade adding even MORE experimentation. Unlike last game where you could only posess Sligs, the gun-toting cyborg henchmen of the Magog Cartel, you can posess EVERYTHING here. Well, except for slogs. Scrabs? Check. Paramites? Check. The Glukkons who you can use to order around Sligs to do your bidding? Checkedy Checkedy Check. These all have their own curveballs, own Gamespeak, and own uses. Even though there aren't too many times you can posess Glukkons, and Phleg... Oh god, that part in Bonewerkz.




[h1] Music and pictures [/h1]



This is where the game gets sublime. And by sublime, I mean some of the best atmosphere, music and art direction you're going to see. The score matches your enviroment perfectly. A few I can list off the top of my head are Necrum, the Mines, the Mudanchee & Mudumo Vaults, and then FeeCo Depot. Be it tribal instruments clashing and meshing to get the feel of a sacred area, or the mechanical and almost oppresive sounds of industrial areas like Necrum Mines or Soulstorm Brewery. All these tracks accompany the backgrounds perfectly. The amount of detail put into these images, the sheer [b]blood and sweat[/b] clearly poored into this was worth the time, creating truly stunning pieces of art, such as all the areas involving the vaults or Necrum, which capture the sacred yet barren forest which has long been forgotten. This doesn't have to be the background either. Character animations, like the floor-wiping Mudokon slaves or even the mere act of climbing ledges or entering doors, are animated as smoothly and realistic as they possibly could be. 


[h1]The Negatives / Sadist Difficulty:[/h1]



For all the good things I've had to say about this game, there is at least one problem with the game, albeit not being a major flaw with the game. This game can be hard. Not just your standard quite challenging levels cropping up a few times, no. Each and every section of this game will have at least one finger-numblingly difficult puzzle or level or just segment. It can either be you can't figure a situation out or you're stuck in one of the game's many chases where you have to run from hostile wildlife and the slimy tentacle cyborgs with machineguns. Only a minor problem, but this will cause a lot of pain.


[h1] My Verdict: [/h1]



Well, what do I think of the game? It is timeless. A truly gorgeous blast from the past which will continue to amaze for quite some time, even if the newer games like Oddworld: Soulstorm flop! [Which I best will be nowhere near happening] If you're thinking about getting this game, go ahead. Only 1.99 pound, or at least for us English, and well worth the small amount of money you take out of your pockets to pay. a 10/10 from yours not so truly, some random person on the internet you probably hate.

26220838.review:
Apesar de ser uma sequela bónus, Abe’s Exoddus não faz parte da Quintologia Oddworld, actualmente composta por Abe’s Oddysee e Munch’s Oddysee. Abe’s Exoddus trouxe consigo vários pontos positivos em relação à jogabilidade, história e atmosfera, tornando o passado e futuro de Mudos cada vez mais complexo, misterioso e emocionante.

Mudos é o continente onde se passa a história de Abe’s Exoddus. Por enquanto, só conhecemos uma pequena fracção das espécies neste continente. Abe é um Mudokon, a espécie natural de Mudos; não é muito inteligente, foi toda a sua vida um escravo, até que descobriu um segredo muito obscuro do local onde trabalhava, RuptureFarms. A companhia pretendia que os Mudokons fossem a nova iguaria do seu mercado alimentar. Foi então que Abe, apercebeu-se que tudo o que tinha visto até ali era apenas a ponta do icebergue. Abe usa os seus lábios selados para o lembrar do seu objectivo, salvar todos os escravos das garras dos Glukkons, os governantes e “senhores” das indústrias de Mudos.

Tal como aconteceu com Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysee, o comentário social sobre a riqueza de uns, a pobreza de outros; o facto de as produções em massa serem um risco de saúde pública, de serem um fardo enorme com a poluição que produzem; de existir espécies e tribos a serem expulsas do seu habitat natural, seja pela matéria prima que obtêm, seja pelo dinheiro que podem ganhar com ela, tudo isto faz parte da história humorística que o jogo tem, mas que se foca em coisas reais e obscuras, provocadas pela humanidade.

Uma das novidades em relação à jogabilidade, é o facto que podermos possuir as míticas espécies selvagens e industriais, tais como o imparável Scrab, o amigo perverso Paramite assim como os estúpidos Sligs e os gananciosos Glukkons. Podemos também possuir gases. Sim, gases. No jogo anterior eram apenas uma piada de fundo, mas neste é uma das novas mecânicas de jogo. Existe uma secção completamente feita a pensar em puzzles deste género. Incrivelmente, funciona bem. Com o poder de possuir outras espécies, podemos também “falar”. Anteriormente, apenas podíamos usar Abe e os Sligs, mas Exoddus torna possível comunicarmos usando qualquer espécie selvagem. Excepto os Fleeches.

A jogabilidade principal é muito similar ao jogo anterior, com apenas algumas alterações, mas esta advém do Prince Of Persia original e Flashback, sendo este último a derradeira inspiração. Abe pode andar, correr, andar pela calada, saltar, fazer salto em comprimento e um variado arsenal de actividades olímpicas, sendo o mais importante a reza, em que ao rezar, Abe pode possuir as espécies que lhe apareçam à frente.

A mecânica integral do jogo poderá ser o Gamespeak, em que ao usarmos combinações de botões, Abe pode comunicar com o mundo à sua volta, seja para ajudar os seus camaradas Mudokons, distrair os Sligs, ordenar as tropas com os Paramites, anunciar a batalha final com os Scrabs ou simplesmente pedir recados com os Glukkons. Os puzzles do jogo anterior conseguiam ser tediosos, pois ordenar cinco Mudokons para um portal conseguia ser um grande problema, mas fazia também parte de uma das mecânicas centrais do jogo. Agora, com o comando “All a Ya”, podemos chamar todos os Mudokons no ecrã e despachar trabalho. Mas nem tudo são rosas.

Com esta nova mecânica, foi introduzida novas formas de a dificultar. Agora existem vários tipos de Mudokons: os doentes, que apenas com o remédio obedecem aos vossos comandos; os furiosos, que terão que pedir desculpa para eles vos seguirem; os “felizes”, que por uso de gás hilariante, tornam-se insuportáveis, e portanto, merecem uma boa chapada; os depressivos, que por terem visto um colega a morrer, apenas vos seguem se pedirem desculpa, sendo que podem tornar-se mesmo suicidas; e por fim, os cegos, que como trabalham nas minas, não devem ver as ossadas e têm que ser devidamente guiados durante o jogo.

A história, muito resumidamente e sem estragar nada, trata-se de Abe tentar salvar os seus camaradas, enquanto desactiva as minas Necrum, onde estão enterrados os seus antepassados. Mas Abe apercebe-se do grande plano dos Glukkons, de tornar as ossadas dos seus antepassados em bebida energética. Então, o objectivo torna-se em parar a fábrica Soulstorm, a todo o custo. E para isso, ele tem a ajuda dos seus amigos e dos três “Estranhos”, que guiam Abe pela sua nova aventura.

A atmosfera de Abe’s Exoddus é mais colorida do que Abe’s Oddysee, mas não deixa de ser intrigante, obscura e por vezes macabra. Os barulhos de fundo, seja o andar dos Sligs ou apenas pássaros, associados à excelente banda sonora, torna a atmosfera ainda mais completa e rica. Este é um daqueles jogos em que a atmosfera nos toma de surpresa e prende-nos até ao fim. A tecnologia usada pelo jogo é uma mistura de gráficos previamente renderizados e sprites, tornando o jogo mais leve, pois a ideia original era completamente em 3D, mas a PlayStation não era forte o suficiente para tal, e teriam que diminuir a qualidade de apresentação. Então o projecto tornou-se 2.5D.

O jogo tem um jogabilidade excelente e intuitiva, ambiente e gráficos mantêm-se muito bem, mesmo após quase vinte anos, e tem uma história única e progressiva, em que apesar do jogo tocar nos assuntos muito levemente, são assuntos sérios e reais, que cada vez mais tomam protagonismo no nosso dia-a-dia. E como tal, devem pegar nestas duas pérolas e jogar do princípio ao fim.


█ F.S.

I absolutely love this game. I love it so much, I spent a month only playing this game and saved all the Mudokans. I didn't grow up with the Oddworld games, but earlier this year I picked up the first on PS1. I honestly didn't have much fun. The game is good, but I would rather play it on an emulator where I can save anytime I wanted. So when I heard Abe's Exoddus had the ability to save and quicksave where ever and when ever I wanted (and needed) to, I got excited. And to be perfectly honest, I perfer the keyboard controls over the controller. I feel it's better for this kind of game, where you have to execute a quick set of movemens in a quick succession (like when you have to run and then roll into a hole. I didn't like how my movements felt pretty clunky on the PS1 version of Abe's Oddysee.

Some Pros:
The story is great (play the game to find out)
The Mudokans are the most adorable things I've ever seen (I don't think the blind guys are scary)
The controls can be changed to make movement fluid
You can possess almost everything (even your own farts after you drink some SoulStorm)
The cutscenes are great
(This is just a little thing, but I love how some Mudokans' voices can be really high or really low)
(Another small thing, but I like Abe's new voice)

Some Cons:
The game is old, so the steam overlay and screenshot functions don't work
Sometimes alt-tabbing out would crash the game, and saving on one screen completely crashed everything (I'm guessing somewhere in Necrum)
The graphics are pretty low-res, and the cutscenes are pretty blurry(but I still love the cutscenes)

TL,DR
Buy this game and you will be happy if you're fine with quicksaving a lot

23144164.review:
Not only is this a fantastic game, an instant 10/10, the fact that it costs only £2 makes it one of the best value-for-money games I've ever seen on Steam, at least not including sales. It took me 20 hours to complete this game, so that's £1 per 10 hours.
The game itself is a classic, growing on what made Abe's Oddysee so great, and while I think Exoddus lacks the atmosphere that made the original so enjoyable, the gameplay itself is much more varied (though I still prefer Oddysee). The cutscenes are better, the music is more complex (if not a tad generic), there are more places and environments to see, and there are more types of puzzles based on the emotion system with the Mudokons. They can be angry, depressed, wired (in other words happy), sick, and blind. This means a lot more is explored as to how the Mudokons interact with you, and especially trying to handle the wired Mudokons running about with enemies, bombs and motion sensors around can get very tense.
You can also autosave, another improvement from Oddysee that makes the game much less frustrating.
I have 2 complaints, however; the first being there are a few ridiculous chase sections that force you to duck and react quickly with a movement system not internded for fast-paced action, rather slow-moving stealth. The game also overstays it's welcome a bit, getting dragged out for a few more hours than it really needed to last.
Speaking of stealth, once again every single enemy can make your palms sweat all over your controller, especially if you have some blind Mudokons you have to escort.
One more thing; the graphics, for 1998, are amazing. I found myself stopping and gazing at some of the fantastically detailed backdrops of places like Necrum and the Soulstorm Brewery. It's dark and beautifully rendered.

Anyway, get the game now. It's bloody great.

I have not played very much but I have seen already that this game is very different from other games, just like it's predecessor. I would say if you are interested in weird and just different games, this would be a good choice. However, there are some things that are holding it back from being a musthave. 

Firstly, the controls are aweful. In the game every button is called Bsomething. They will say like "To talk to your friends press B4 + B4". Neither a keyboard nor a Xbox Controller have these buttons. I have kind of figured out by myself what the controls are now, but it's very weird they didn't include at least a picture with the control scheme. 

Secondly, it's way too easy to die. You die from falling if you fall down 2 floors. sometimes you don't know how many floors you will fall since it's offscreen. You also die from 1 bullet, so do the slaves you are rescuing. I am very happy it's so easy to save otherwise I wouldn't have even played the first 30 minutes. 

I have no problem with the games visuals or sound. They are the best the PS1 could offer.

19087972.review:
Fantastic sequel to Abe's Oddysee!

This game adds more than what Oddysee had. More characters to mind control, more Game Speak commands, variety of environments and colors, new obstacles, and of course, you can lead every Mudokens in the same area with the press of a key instead of having to talk to them individually.

Pros:
+Beautifuly rendered environments for the time
+Humorous cutscenes
+Tight Controls
+Chilling atmosphere
+Memorable sound effects and voice clips
+Quicksave
++YOU CAN CONTROL YOUR OWN FARTS

Cons:
-Some ledges/platforms are blending in the background which makes them hard to see (or maybe I'm just blind)
-A lot of trial on error (could be considered a nitpick)
-Delay when pressing certain keys
-Game Speak feels clunky sometimes
-Expect a lot of wall hitting

Overall, I can't think of any major negatives; the good stuff outshines the bad stuff. I've personally never owned a PS1, but playing it for the first time on Steam after many years of its release, it still feels fresh. Worth replaying to rescue all Mudokens!

17930589.review:
I was 3 years old when this game was released, I was 6 years old when I first started playing it, I was 10 years old when I was finally good enough at it to finish it and I was 12 when I was finally good enough at it to get a good ending. A game cannot be bad if it held my attention for that long, it cannot even be just good if it held my attention for 6 years. There are games which I've abandoned a while ago and never tried to finish, Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus is a game I never trully abandoned because it was too good of a game to fully abandon, regardless of how hard I found the Vault sections (which prevented me from making any progress for years), regardless of how disheartening it was to get a bad ending on my first complete playthrough.

Everything about this game is awesome, the story, the gameplay, the graphics, the characters, the voice acting, the social themes, everything. Words cannot do justice to this game, to paraphrase Morpheus: "Nobody can be told what Oddworld is, you'd have to experience it for yourself." 

This is the kind of game that I love so much and I've played through so much that I can practically recite it from memory. Every person has that one game that they grew up with, the game that defined their childhood, for some it's Super Mario Bros. or Final Fantasy, for others it's Metal Gear Solid or Baldur's Gate. For me it's this game, I love this game, I love everything about this game, from its amazing stealth and platforming mechanics, to its beautiful environments that put most modern games to shame. If there's any game that I can recommend without any reservations, it's this one.

And please do drop some money for its slightly inferior but still worthwhile predecessor Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee. Both games are really cheap so there's no way you'll be wasting your money.

17697002.review:
PROS:

Probably my favorite game of all time. This game has some of the BEST cutscenes, if not THE best cutscenes for the PS1 and early PC era. Gameplay is smooth, and for me, It ran without errors on my windows 8 machine, with a medium graphics card. The idea for the game is AMAZING, you play as Abe, a mudoken hero who must free his mudoken pals from soul storm brewery, and other amazingly beautiful and well designed places. The difficulty is completely fair, and, If you die, it is completely your fault, not the fault of the game or any cheap enemies, like in the last game. This game also features quick saves, possibly the best thing lovely lorne luscious lanning has ever came up with. gamespeak has been changed slightly, and a new command was added to have abe say "all a' ya!" where all of the mudokens in the room would follow, even ones in the distant background.

CONS:
While in some rooms, the game makes the player throw rocks at mines that cannot be disarmed. This is extremely tedious, especially when you have long rows of mines to destroy. When you set off a mine, you would expect it to set off all the surrounding ones, right? well no. You have to hit EACH FUCKING MINE to destroy them, and once in a blue hand moon a mine might detonate another. You can also only carry 9 rocks, and you cannot refil your bag of rocks until you throw each one. pain in the ASS. in addition, you have to release the Z key (Throwing key) after each rock you throw. if you hold it, and choose which way you want to throw it, abe will walk in that direction, towards whatever mine or bone drill you are trying to avoid

There is laughing gas in this game. Which on paper is a good concept, but in the game it can be very frustrating and unfair. First off, if one of your following mudokens is exposed to laughing gas, they go apeshit. making you slap them to calm them down. But what usually happens, especially if you have a large following of gas-high mudokens, is you can accidentaly slap a mudoken that you have already slapped. pissing him off, and he slaps you back. then you have to go and say sorry to him to calm him down. and when you're finally done with all that, one of your gas high mudokens has already ran straight into the barrel of a fucking slig.

But when you put all the bullshit aside, you end up with one of the best games every made, and probably the best of the whole oddworld trilogy. but that is bound to change when Squeeks oddysee is released.

17660997.review:
I can honestly say that this is my absolute favourite game ever, and I am happy that it's on Steam since my PS1 broke down. I really believe that this game gets heavily overlooked when it comes to naming the top games of its generation. Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee gets mentioned quite a bit, but this one... not so much. Which is a damn shame, and I'll explain why in a minute.

The only downside to this was getting it playable was a little difficult. Resolution issues are the first big problem, though that was easy to fix with a quick download of a program. Now the only minor annoyance is that because its natural resolution was 800x600, stretching that to my 1920x1080 caused it to because a little more pixelated and blurry. You can still see everything perfectly fine, its mostly just distant objects or background things during the cutscenes that may be difficult to make out.
Controller compatibility isn't labelled, but it [i]is[/i] there, to a degree. I was prepared to use my Xbox 360 controller, but the default mapped controls for it were a mess (chanting was the 'Back' button of all buttons). Honestly, it's easier and probably better to just stick with the keyboard. Any remapping you deem necessary is much less stressful.

As for the gameplay... If you've played Abe's Oddysee, then everything you saw there was improved on here, and for the better. Extra voice commands, emotions of the Mudokons to deal with, often in hilarious ways (particularly with the laughing gas). Possession of enemies ranges further than sligs (who also now have a flying variation). The wider range of enemies, the much more intimidating puzzles, the fact that the major bad guys are actually a within bits and pieces of the game and become a mechanic themselves rather than just be seen and death with via cutscenes... and at its worst, some areas just require careful timing. The game is incredibly simple for the things you can do.

The backgrounds for the environments are spectacular, the music... isn't the stuff of legends, but I have found myself humming or whistling a couple of the tunes here and there. But otherwise the only other major factor is the story, and it's just as weird and twisted as the original. It kicks off right where Oddysee ended (poor Abe doesn't even get time to rest).
And here's a fun fact. Back in the late 90's when this game originally came out, most of this games cutscenes were turned into a short film. A short film that was nominated for an Oscar. A goddamn [b]Academy Award[/b]! Technically speaking, the first and (I could be wrong with this one) only game to have achieved that.

Besides the questionable performance issues in getting the game going, majority of which easily fixed, I recommend this game and recommend it hard. While I'm at it, I also recommend Abe's Oddysee (or its HD remake 'New n' Tasty'). While it may be a childhood love of mine, it's been 17 years and I can still call it my favourite.
I'm at a point where I can play at least 30% of it with sound alone, and I'm still not sick of this game. It's just that kind of game that I can pick up and play any day of the year.


[b][i]TL;DR[/i][/b] - If you liked Oddysee, you'll like Exoddus better. If you haven't played it, [b][u]PLAY IT![/u][/b]

16587184.review:
[h1]Abe's exoddus's overhauls over abe's oddysee[/h1]
pros:
+improved level design.
+actually very clever and funny writing.
+all of the mechanics have been improved in some shape or form. (even the ones that weren't used on abe's oddysee but were there for no reason and or were re-maps of others now have actual porpuses to be there)
+arguably more colorfull and detailed backgrounds (abe's oddysee had great alien like landscapes that felt sacred,wild,ominous and or dangerous. abe's exoddus feels more like what happens after a big company starts to forage and destroy said landscapes, now entoxicated and more rotten than what it already used to be, but still manages to add more colors and lights to make something enjoyable to stare at)
+great cgi animations (i don't think they were improved but i had to bring it up anyways)
+quicksaves are a thing now.
[h1]Abe's exoddus's flaws[/h1]
cons:
-delayed controls, cinematic platformers have always been somewhat clunky and this one is no exception.
-repeated trends for level design. I swear, there were at least 3 ideas that I saw getting repeated throughout the game.
- no quickloads, meaning that if you don't save after a quicksave you might have to repeat what you just did assuming you screwed up.
[h1]Personal experience[/h1]
the game was super fun to play through, not only was it beautiful to look at, it also happened to be an incredible thrill ride filled satisfying puzzles, funny cutscenes and unique locales to explore.
the game is surprisingly long for its time and genre, ocationally the game can even be pretty spooky which is actually aplaudable for how it plays around with its sound design and fucked up imagery to mess with you, its dirty cheap and a literal steal during steam sales so please do yourself a favor and get this game.

[table]

[h1][u]Old Sequel:[/u][/h1] 
Итак, на дворе 1998 год и в свет выходит продолжение одного из лучших платформеров. Наш жилистый, неуклюжий и обладающий багажом везения, чудаковатый Мудокон снова с нами. [b]Abe's Exoddus[/b] стартует сразу после завершения [b]Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysee[/b], не успев как следует отпраздновать победу, Эйб опять таки случайным образом узнает о новой напасти. Мудоконов эксплуатируют на шахтах для добычи костей предков - основного ингредиента для забористого напитка Глюкконов. В этот раз Эйб уже по собственной воле отправляется на опасное предприятие, широко расправив плечи.
[b]Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee[/b] - довольно самобытный платформер, опередивший свое время и использующий багаж до сих пор, не использованных механик. Вторая часть продолжает развивать уже имеющиеся наработки и очень успешно с этим справляется. Система взаимодействия с соплеменниками прибавила в разнообразии, теперь можно отвесить тумаков, дабы привести в чувства, дать команду приняться за работу или извиниться перед обиженным Мудоконом, конечно если есть перед чем извиняться, зачастую обидная ошибка стоит жизни бедному Мудокону. Все клавиши с 1-9 отвечают сугубо за "социальные таланты". Следующим новшеством стало развитие таланта Эйба - переселятся в тела врагов. Теперь переселиться можно практически в любое существо и даже, со временем, внимание! В газы Эйба. Да-да теперь мы не только сможем пукать но и контролировать процесс. Так же прибавила в разнообразии фауна и даже появились различные виды Мудоконов. 
Ко всему перечисленному игра стала на порядок длиннее, а верховных правителей в лице Глюкконов теперь стало четверо:
[list][i][*]Генерал Дрипик - глава казарм Слигов;
[*]Директор Флег - глава костеперерабатывающей фабрики;
[*]Вице-президент Эслик ("Дядя Эслик") - глава склада, ж/д станции и хранилища; 
[*]Брюмастер - управляющий производством напитка [b]SoulStorm Brew[/b];[/list]
Игра, так же как и предшественница не заставляет вас спасать Мудоконов и даже разрешает их издевательски умертвить, но так же как и в предшественнице это карается плохой концовкой.
Так же разработчики снабдили игру столь нужной функцией - сохранение в любом месте игры. 
В остальном игра осталась верна своему стилю, став чуточку мрачнее, но с тем же юмором, тем же необычным и манящим миром, с тем же не тривиальным гэймплеем.

[h1][i]Игра рекомендуется тем, кого не пугает графика времен конца 90-х и кто впервые познакомился с серией только с переизданием [b]Oddworld: New'n'Tasty[/b], т.к. это пока лучшая возможность продолжить приключения Эйба. Игра поддерживает гэймпад, так что порог вхождения после [b]New'n'Tasty[/b] довольно интуитивный и даже в таком виде игра приносит по сей день массу положительных эмоций и букет гэймплейных находок.[/i][/h1]

[/quote]

14688638.review:
Along the same premise as the first game, the Mudokons you're trying to rescue in Exoddus are much more complex than the original assembly. Besides the occasional drunk, blind, or just generally resistant creature, they all emote like mood rings, showing red skin when angry and an off-color greenish yellow and pale tone when sick. You have to find healing rings from Shaman Mudokons and apologize and shoulder-pat to make angry ones happy again so they'll follow you to safety. And blind Mudokons have a tendency to walk into drills and off of ledges if you don't guide them properly with verbal cues. On a positive note, you can use their blindness to your benefit. For example, if a blind Mudokon is on the level below you, notably the one with the lever you need to pull but can't get to, you can stand on the side of the screen you want the blind guy to walk toward, prompt him to follow you, and then tell him to "work" in order to turn the crank or pull the lever that allows you access to another level. Another excellent function is being able to guide more than one Mudokon at a time. In the first game, you had to rescue one Mudokon, then come back and get the other one. In Exoddus, you have an "All o' ya" command that captures the attention of anyone present. At points, you'll have a gaggle trailing behind you - sneaking, running, or jumping into the bird teleporters.

But perhaps even better than the hammed-up gamespeak is the fact that the developers fixed what could easily be called the number one problem with the first game: the inability to save the game wherever you wanted. Not only was Abe's Oddysee a tough game, you spent a lot of time redoing what you'd done because of the need to learn the hard way. Many of the puzzles in the original required some testing before you made it through, and when you have to go all the way back to the beginning of the path each time you fail, it's hard to stay inspired to push forward. In Exoddus, you have an incredibly welcomed quick-save option that allows you to quickly save your progress, anywhere in the game as many times as you want. And when you're ready to quit playing, you simply save to the memory card instead of a quick save, and you're set. This introduces an interesting dilemma, as the quick save certainly makes Exoddus seem easier, in a sense, but the game itself is actually even more difficult than the first one - it's just that now you finally have hope. And just when you think hope's lost, something wonderful like an invisibility power-up appears when you free Mudokon spirits.

Graphically, Abe's Exoddus is the same 2D visual wonder, much like the original or, moreover, Interplay's Heart of Darkness. Yet the graphics seem much more brilliant, as there are more environments with greater diversity in design. And the cutscenes are not only gorgeous, they're entertaining and (can I say it?) funny. No, really. Besides that, the game is quite large, and the environments are expansive. You'll have to rescue the spirits of Mudokons past; battle the typical, yet enhanced cast of Sligs, Scrabs, and the excruciatingly annoying Fleeches (long live the quick save), among others; as well as roll through the mines in mine carts and such. And sound-wise, you really can't get much better without being downright distracting. The voices of all the characters are incredible, and the effects, from getting blown up by a mine to the echoey sound of falling to your death, really can't be beat.

Abe's Exoddus also has a two-player mode. While the Exoddus mainstay is clearly the single-player game, the two-player co-op mode does have charm, as you and another player take turns working your way through. When you die, your partner picks up where you left off and so forth. A bit of advice? Pick a crummy partner, and you might have some fun with this. Otherwise, the waiting game just doesn't parallel the egocentric fun of keeping this title to yourself. In all, Abe's Exoddus is a great example of how a game can stay true to its conceptual pursuit while still improving upon the original, all while keeping its soul intact. If you loved the first one, you'll like this game more. If you didn't play the first one, you can start here. If you hated the first one, it's likely because of the lack of save points, so you should definitely consider giving this series another try.

I remeber when I was still a kid & walking the shopping centre with my dad & he discided to into a store where they had DVDs & games on sale & comng past Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus is the first game I spotted for the playstation 1.  The reason why I wanted it, because I have the Demo1 disc of the first game & I final got the full copy of the game while sometime in high school when stores like GAME stopped putting them old PS1 games instore.

I do have the copy of this game on PS1, but never expranice the full game, because the game froze when Abe jumped in the well the Scrab temple, but Paramites temple was pretty aswsome, then I never really bothered with cheat code books that my uncle from England sent over to me years before with a copy of Crash Bandicoot 3.  I did complete the game a few years later by using the the level cheat code.

Now that I am 19 going on 20 & have a laptop that runs windows 8 that can play some games like Five nights at freddy's.  Seeing British youtuber Caddicarus doing a retrospective of the first three games & saying at the end of part 3 that the games are on steam.  Well I downloaded the demo of this one & worked fine, then I bought it.


Story: 

Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus takes place straight after the first when Abe saved all the mudokons from Repture Farms.  After having a fall & getting knocked out that laid him to having a vision of three ghosts telling him that the Glukkons are digging up there bones.  So Abe & five friends set off across the dessert to Necrum to put an end to it.

Along the way Abe finds out what why the Gulkkon digging up Mudokon bones for a drink called Soul Strom Brew that is made from there bones, whitch takes Abe to another journy to the burial vaults of Necrum and temples of Scrabs, Paramites & Fleeches to get the ablity to cure sick mudokons. 

Whats new:

With the character in game & in cutscenes sounds different from the first with, but with a deeper voice & then goes high when changes from saying "Hello" to "Hi" when using game speak as you progressing more into the game.  

Some of the cast of characters from the last game are back including the gun crazy Sligs that can now fly & shoot granades & ones without pants & the Glukkons, Scrabs, Paramites & slogs return also.  There are some new characters like the blined mudokons, Fleeches, worm-like creatures that live in the Oddworld underworld that will take a few shots to eat Abe in one whole & Slurgs when stepped on will wake up the Feeches when sleeping.     

What I liked:

I like that I was able to us my PS4 controller to play the game like I did on the PS1 without having to use my keyboard on my laptop.  Getting to possess Glukkons, Scrabs & Paramites for the first time & using there very own game speak which is neat.

The game runs really well & has a faster loading time & at a good low price.  You can run this game on any PC.

What I hated:

I got nothing besides the D-pad not doing anything.
 
Final Thought:

Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus has a great  sence of humor, good voice acting & level design, including amazing art that shows in the games background & in cutscenes. 

Is this worth your time?  Yes.   Its still a great game to this day.  I still do enjoy this game when ever I go back to play it after a long time.

13882341.review:
Agora sim. O jogo que eu sempre quis analisar. Eu cresci jogando isso, e não me arrependo um dia sequer de ter jogado.

Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus é um jogo feito pela Oddworld Inhabitants em 1998. Por mais que o jogo pareça uma sequência do Oddysee, na realidade não é, pois o Oddysee é o primeiro da Quintologia Oddworld, e o Munch's Oddysee é o segundo de acordo com os devs, então o Exoddus fica como um "jogo bônus". (apesar de eu considerá-lo uma sequência ótima)

A história se passa diretamente depois do Oddysee, onde Abe, depois de voltar de Rupturefarms, tem uma visão de espíritos de nativos Mudokons mortos relatando roubo de ossos de Necrum, o "cemitério" dos Mudokons nativos, para produzir Soulstorm Brew, um tipo de bebida fabricada pelos Glukkons (sim, não basta tentar usar a carne dos Mudokons, agora usam os ossos também). Assim, Abe parte para as minas de Necrum com um grupo de Mudokons para tentar descobrir a verdade.

Dá pra dizer que é um "Oddysee 2.0", pois o gameplay, os gráficos, as músicas e a temática do jogo continuam os mesmos. Recomendo ler meu review sobre o Oddysee para saber como é. Porém existem várias melhorias e coisas novas. Por exemplo, agora pode-se chamar vários Mudokons de uma vez, ao invés de chamar um por um como se fazia no Oddysee (e que foi implementado no New 'N' Tasty). O Exoddus também contém um sistema de QuickSave, marca agora característica da OWI, onde você salva o jogo no lugar EXATO onde você estava. Não é só na mesma fase e na mesma tela, é NO LUGAR EXATO onde você estava quando deu o save, ao contrário dos checkpoints invisíveis do Oddysee.

Entre outras mudanças, o jogo agora possui Sligs voadores (parecem mini-helicópteros), e também dá pra possuir Scrabs e Paramites, coisa que não era possível no Oddysee (isso está fortemente ligado à história, então não dá pra contar). O jogo também possui Glukkons para serem possuídos durante o jogo, enquanto no Oddysee eram apenas Sligs. Cada um tem seu próprio GameSpeak. O jogo também é um pouco mais longo que o antecessor, possui alguas fases a mais e... ah, quase que eu esqueço de mencionar: lembra dos 99 Mudokons de Rupturefarms? Agora tem 300 Mudokons pra salvar nesse jogo. Boa sorte amigo, eu nunca passei de 250.

Não tem muito o que dizer, mas se você gostou do Oddysee, o Exoddus é um must-have. Eu tenho até hoje o CD original dos dois, do Oddysee (no PS1) e do Exoddus (no PC), mas quando eu os vi na Steam, não tinha como não comprar. Agora sim eu literalemnte liguei minha alma a esses dois jogos e à franquia Oddworld.


+PRÓS:
+Todos os prós do Oddysee, melhorados
+Mecãnicas novas, possibilidades novas
+Dificuldade aumentada, 300 Mudokons contra os 99 do Oddysee
+Outro clássico indispensável

-CONTRAS:
-Assim como o Oddysee, a resolução é baixa e os gráficos ficam "pixelados", já que foram feitos na mesma engine, porém isso não afeta em nada a nota final

NOTA FINAL: um fecking 10/10 merecidíssimo, se pudesse dava 11

13669583.review:
Very slightly more light-hearted than Oddysee, but still retains the dark settings and characters which Munch's Oddysee and Stranger's Wrath lack. If you fancy a challenge, I would actually recommend this sequel over the original, as I found it a bit easier to get to grips with. Also, the controls have been tweaked slightly since the last game making Abe's "chant" move easier to access on the keyboard.

There are times when you'll have cracked a puzzle or found a hidden door that leave you quite pleased with yourself - this is the kind of feeling you play it for! That sense of reward, being one step closer to saving all your Mudukon chums. (And yes, I do mean ALL of them. Honestly, play the game the way it's meant to be played)

Also, I noticed a number of negative reviews referring to cutscene and freezing glitches - Guys, GET ODDPATCH! It's a nifty little .exe that runs in the background and fixes all the bugs. Just use a search engine and you'll find it.

Get the Oddboxx while it's still on sale, you won't regret it! Great value!

13148461.review:
Oddworld Abe´s Exoddus is the perfect sequel for the first game of the series.
Well it´s larger to begin, beeing like 2x the size of the predecessor, with more of a variety at the sceneries with huge beauty and detail with the seal of Oddworld, plus 300 mudokons to save this time!  Abe´s Exoddus introduces us certain elements that improves the gameplay like the emotional state of mudokons, the explosive farts that you will need to use in order to advance later in the game, and most importantly, the introduction of Quicksave that substitutes the "annoying" checkpoints that existed in Abe´s Oddysee. Story-wise it feels like the first game only with a different twist, this time involving the glukkons using the mudokon´s bones and tears to produce an addictive drink leading to an amazing journey in one wonderful journey of epic 2-D that marked a generation, helping Abe saving his fellow mudokons from slavery, and also saving himself!

11748515.review:
While Abe's Oddysee certainly deserves a lot of credit, it is not without fault. The excellent level design, short-but-sweet story, and grand scope of it was hampered predominantly by its checkpoint system. Each portion of a stage would throw three or four challenges at you between each checkpoint, not counting any hidden mudokons. As a result, there were many cases when several parts of a particular stage were easy but fairly slow and time consuming, while later parts were significantly more difficult and led to multiple deaths. Having to replay the earlier, easier parts quickly became very tedious very fast. In some games, this sort of thing doesn't hurt the game, but here, where the gameplay is built around trial and error, and often demands a great deal of patience, it killed the pacing at several points towards the beginning and middle of the game.

I'm mentioning this because Abe's Exoddus included a quicksave feature which circumvented this problem, and for that reason alone could be considered a better game. That's not the only feather in Abe's Exoddus' cap though. The inclusion of such a feature as quicksave can fundamentally change a game like this, and Oddworld Inhabitants clearly kept this in mind. The level design is more challenging than Abe's Oddysee, but more fair. Secrets, previously pretty cryptic and very easy to overlook without the help of a guide, are now found by some out-of-the-box thinking and creative use of the game's mechanics. The core gameplay and overall design have been tweaked to remove tedium. The mechanics have been greatly expanded upon in order to provide much more variety and complexity. The voice acted cutscenes lend the world much more character, and add a great deal of levity to a game that could very easily become quite depressing.

No matter how you look at it, Abe's Exoddus is the better of the two side scrolling games (as of writing this, New 'n' Tasty is still PS4 exclusive, so I can't comment on it yet). It manages to correct the flaws of it's predecessor while also expanding upon everything that was good. It really is what every sequel should strive to be. More of the good, plenty that's new, none of the bad.

9368765.review:
Пожалуй, поиграть для меня в сей шедевр, полный креатива, который буквально кишит таковым - не просто побывать в удивительном мире, преподносимым для игрока разработчиком; и также не просто воспоминанья шли вслед за мною попятам, покуда я играл. Игра, что сделана на века, а таких по числу не столь-то и обильное множество - и то можно сказать наверняка, когда предстоит провести незабываемое время в игре Oddworld. Данная часть была мне самой первой, ещё на тот самый Sony Playstation 1. Уже позже я начну выражать сожаленье, что не играл - ОКАЗЫВАЕТСЯ-ТО! - в самую первую часть, не знал, что за Rupture Farms, кто таков Molluk, но позже жизнь дозволила мне узреть и первую часть. Об том я беспредельно радый, ведь как "завсегдатай" данной игры, я сознательно обязывал знать, каково оно было то первоначало игре Oddworld.
Странный мир - поначалу я ошибочно переводил его даже "Другой мир", из-за частицы в слове - "Odd". Однако мир этот был для меня и навсегда останется что странным, что, с большим благолепием, другим, а под другим я станусь подразумевать чудной, но и причудливый, такой удивительный, насыщенный. Как же поработало сознанье человеческое! Сколько творческого вложенья осуществлено! Этот труд не может кануть в небытие. Впервой я играл собственнолично в платформер, который заставил заглядываться на все эти background'ные фоны, оформленья, начиная дикими джунглями Necro и продолжая в великолепнейшей бесконечности всеми остальными мирами, которые в такой амальгаме представил Oddworld Inhabitants. Это есть идеальный ресурс для фан-арта: фан-фикшины, рисунки, всем этим плескаться вдоволь можно каждому добровольцу, кто встанет на творческое поприще, как на фронт, ради данной игры. Конечно, не нужно прилагать столь фанатичной самоотверженности, однако я решился сказаться об том, как верно глаголит слово поэтическое, "С чувством, с толком, с расстановкой". Здесь мало попросту поднять палец вверх и сказать, по моему мненью, несколько неблагодарное и бессодержательное "Нравится".
Охрана, - Слиги - дикие животные, - Скрабы, Парамиты - Глюконы, кои явились олицитвореньем алчности, жадности, над которыми властвует нажива и личная выгода, да притом производственная - все эти существа.. Да они попросту необъятны для моего слова, но вполне умещаются в сознаньи, притом с самого верного беззаветного и безмятежного детства. Это всё настолько сочетается гармонично, что один элемент без другого попросту не сосуществует, и это именуется систематичностию. Атмосферность писанных саундтреков ничуть не уступает в качестве подачи игры. Забывайте про графику, отошлите этот элемент в сторону, за занавес, подалее от вашего восприятья, в противном же материализм в восприятии придаст ядовитой придирчивости и тогда игра мозайкой развалится прямо у вас на глазах. Но, что нисколько не удивляет, фанатов хватает, потому судить верно можно и с уверенностью об том, каковой успех создатель продвинул в игровую индустрию, точнее, уж сам коллектив.

9114124.review:
ALL OF THE NOSTALGIA!!! From the very first sounds of the opening sequence and game menu, I was instantly transported back to late 1990's, sitting in my older brother's bedroom, playing this on classic playstation and a tiny, heat-warped telly that we had to use a bit of blue-tac and a screw to keep the switch on AV (occassionally the screw would come loose and we'd suddenly be plunged into static mid-game!). My brother and I would take turns playing, switching every time we got Abe killed (which, on my part, was normally almost instantly), jumping out of our skins at the scarier parts (this game had the best graphics we'd ever seen at the time) and laughing our arses off at all the fart jokes. We had played through Oddysee pretty quickly, so we were excited to have a much longer game this time (TWO whole discs!), with slightly better graphics, and OH THAT REALLY AWESOME QUICKSAVE FUNCTION! Our mum even got in on the action, and played this with us on more than one occassion, helping us out with the more "puzzle-solving" sections that we couldn't work out (plus she is an x-files fanatic and loves everything to do with Aliens and weird shit like that). 

So for me, this game is totally worth playing, even though it definitely wasn't designed to be played with a keyboard, nor on a 27" HD screen. It brings back so many fond memories of the rare moments that my brother and I were working together to keep Abe alive and rescue all of the Mudokons, instead of at each others throats trying to kill each other. I still love the quirky nature of this game/universe - the artwork and landscapes are mind-blowing to me even now that the graphics are incredibly below-par. The characters and creatures of Oddword are so unique and terrifying. I love the 2D platform gameplay - I wish there were more games like this. Some of the levels are pretty easy, and some of them are infuriatingly difficult (for me anyway), which just makes completing them all the more rewarding :) Just don't be a dunce like me and forget that you've only been Quicksaving for the last 3 hours, decide to exit after completing a particularly difficult level and forget to do a proper Save... That shit is devistating.

So yeah, if you loved playing this game when it first came out, you won't regret playing it again :) It's everything I remember and more. 

If you've never played it before, give it a go! It was ahead of it's time when it came out like 15 years ago, and it's still a unique gaming experience in a lot of ways. If nothing else, the story is fantastic. The implications and irony of the story is something you just don't get in many popular games. We sympathize with the Mudokons and their hero, Abe. But most of us, if we took a hard look at ourselves, probably fall into the Glukkon or Slig category... or the kind of Muddokon that just watches it all happen and does nothing.

HD re-make coming soon??? AMAZIIIIING!!!

7747464.review:
Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus is a landmark game, and worthy sequel to the original Abe's Oddysee.

Even in its now-limited screen resolution, the strong visual design of Abe's Exoddus shines through. Don't expect to run this game at your native resolution (unless you never upgraded beyond 800x600 - in which case, you're in luck!), but do expect the following: some fantastic and challenging platforming gameplay; a vast number of gorgeous levels interwoven with an interesting, dark and downright odd narrative; some brilliant music which changes dynamically depending on the events taking place; and finally, some fiendish puzzles which make use of Abe's talent for posession and the use of GameSpeak - a system by which you can instruct other characters to whatever ends you desire, be it salvation or something more nefarious.

If you've played it before, there's no better time to return to the original Oddworld titles before enjoying the delights of the HD Remake, New N' Tasty, which recreates the events of the original game in a modern game engine and is "coming soon". If you're new to the series, don't be put off by the age or initial difficulty curve. Exoddus has a quick save system, so you'll never lose progress as long as you're diligent. A must-play!

615347.review:
ABE'S ODDYSEE was the beginning.  Lorne Lanning stated EXODDUS was meant less a separate sequel and more a "bonus game" to ODDYSEE.

Now, ODDYSEE was something special and you should love it.  But the difficulty level was...intimidating, to say the least.  Just beating it feels like a miracle--but beating it while finding, and then getting 100% on the secret bonus stuff?  FUGGEDABOUTIT.

EXODDUS has all the challenge, gorgeous art and design, weird humor, and more loveable characters (Paramites.  Paramites paramites paramites) that showed up in ODDYSEE--but then adds variety and Quicksaves (thank goodness for quicksaves!) and THEN makes the bonuses COMPLETELY DOABLE.  

EXODDUS is a pantheon-level game.  You will break a sweat beating this game, and you will feel like a world champion every time you beat a puzzle and you will love it for making you feel this way.  

It's hard to imagine any game getting better than this.

2959809.review: I would definitely recommend ANY of the oddworld series, truth be told, Abe's Exoddus is the only one that I have played extensively, but I have also played Stranger's Wrath back on the Xbox, and it was insane! These games are completely unique in their story, and perhaps the only games I have ever seen that could portray the entrapment of an entire species in such a humorous way. Abe's Exoddus is somewhat a platformer, but with many puzzle aspects. The point is to save all of your enslaved species because the spirits of your ancestors all tell you to, so Abe does just that. Unlike the previous game in the series, they make it so you MUST save other mudokon's in order to progress. If you want a game with little consequences (besides getting a non-canon ending) and lets of freedom to destroy creatures in all variety of somewhat gruesome situations, play the previous game, which I would encourage you do either way. However, Abe's Exoddus will forever remain my favorite.

4237049.review:
MY game of the year... every year.
Absolute personal favorite of mine. Played it on PS1 and bought it again after seeing it here on Steam because that's just how much I loved this game. I finished the game multiple times while rescuing all Mudokons, with and without cheats, and even somehow got 3 extra Mudokons without the use of cheats or intentional glitches if I did any at all.

This version is perhaps superior to the PS1 version being that things load lightning fast on almost any computer today and has rebindable keys (though some keys get weird with binding and setting up a joypad is even weirder).

To me, this is one of the best examples of a game where timing is absolutely essential for avoiding hazards that can kill you and your buddies while keeping you focused on how to proceed. The whole game got a lot easier though compared to Oddysee with the new QUIKSAVE feature but its essential purpose for that however was to replace the old checkpoint system in the previous game thus leading to much fewer frustrations if you die/fail as there are loads of precise timing involved now, especially for the secret areas.

For one, they made an already incredibly difficult game, even more challenging. Clunky controls combined with trial and error gameplay where perfection is required leaves this as one of the most frustrating games ever made. The atmosphere, enemies, and art direction is great like the previous game, however I felt they took a backseat this time, with alot of the areas this time looking very similar in an even longer game. Also there were no elums this time around so that was disappointing lol. New gameplay stuff like controlling the Glukkons and invisibility were pretty neat. I always love seeing new enemies so the new editions were exciting as well. Overall, the game is awesome. It's just not the best to play. The game is unfairly hard and lengthy that you will quickly lose interest. Don't even bother trying to save all the Mudokons if you care about your sanity. Some are hidden so ridiculously you would never have found them on your own. Abe's Exoddus is a relentless experience with less variety this time around, which made it hard for me to stick with it. I still recommend it, though. It's cheap, fun, and is still a great game despite all my complaints. I love Oddworld's source material which keeps me playing despite my frustrations and i'm sure it will probably interest you, too. Favorite part was the Slig news anchor LMAO.

39666714.review:
Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus is the followup of Oddworld Abe's Oddysee. Abe is out once again on a rescue mission to save his friends from an evil corporation. This time his friends aren't becoming food, but the new alcoholic beverage! 

Abe's Exoddus is, just like the first game, a 2D platform game in which you have to sneak, run, use the enviroment and take control of the enemy to save your friends. Compared to Abe's Oddysee this game has a few sweet extra features though!

One thing I find really amazing about this game is that you can take control of more than just the standard slig enemies. You can also take control of various other creatures that you could only try running away from in the first game.

Your buddies that you have to save have also decided to adapt more various personality. There are the overly happy ones that you have to literally slap back to reality before they'll listen to you. The sad ones that you'll have to cheer up ( careful, if they get too sad they might kill themselves!), the angry ones who will try to hit you or even kill you until you apologise to them and blind ones that you have to make sure they'll stop in time before they run into something that will kill them!

The game, just like the original, runs very smooth on any PC and is bugfree. If you enjoyed Abe's Oddysee, you just have to get this one as well! If you didn't: The intro has a pretty cool video to explain to you what you missed in the first game. This way you don't feel completely clueless in the story.
